newsitem.title: FRANCE: Moslem rebels kill 28 villagers in Algeria - paper.
newsitem.headline: Moslem rebels kill 28 villagers in Algeria - paper.

text.p: Suspected Moslem guerrillas have killed 28 people, including women and children, in two raids in northern Algeria this week, an Algerian newspaper said on Saturday.
Rebels, armed with hatchets and shotguns, killed 22 villagers in Seghouane hamlet near Medea town, some 70 km (45 miles) southwest of Algiers, El Watan newspaper said.
Among the victims were women and children and a whole family of nine members decimated in the raid on Thursday night, it said.
In another raid on Wednesday night, rebels cut the throats of six peasants in Bourouss village in Tipaza province, 60 km (40 miles) west of Algiers, El Watan added.
The reported massacres in the two villagers coincided with bomb attacks in Algiers this week.
Eight people were killed and 10 others were wounded on Thursday when a bomb ripped through a minibus operating in El Harrach district southwest of Algiers, Al Khabar newspaper said on Saturday.
A bomb on Wednesday wounded 40 people aboard a train in El Harrach, according to residents.
At least 200 civilians have been killed in the outbreak of violence since the June 5 general election in Algeria, Al Khabar added.
President Liamine Zeroual has barred radical Islamists from this month's election but allowed moderate Moslem fundamentalists to compete in the poll.
An estimated 60,000 people have been killed in Algeria since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election in which radical Islamists had taken a huge lead.
